sen.j: 国役（こくやく/くにやく）とは、平安時代から南北朝時代 (日本)にかけて朝廷及び国衙が諸国に課した雑役・一国平均役などの課役のこと。
sen.e: Kuniyaku is labor duties, such as zatsueki (odd-job tasks) and Ikkoku heikinyaku (taxes and labor uniformly imposed on shoen (manor) and kokugaryou (provincial land) in a province), imposed by the Imperial Court and kokuga (provincial government offices) from the Heian period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

sen.e: By extension, it refers to labor duties, such as tansen (a kind of provisional tax in medieval Japan), imposed on Shugo daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable) and each province by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and labor duties imposed by the Shugo daimyo on their own territories.

sen.j: 律令制の崩壊後、朝廷は造内裏役や役夫工米などを名目に国衙を通じて雑役（臨時雑役・雑公事）や一国平均役などを国衙領や荘園などに課していった。
sen.e: After a breakdown of the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), the Imperial Court imposed zatsueki (temporary labor work and zoukuji (other labor work)) and Ikkoku heikinyaku on Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) and shoen (manor in medieval Japan) through kokuga in the name of zodairi-yaku (a public duty) or yakubukumai (a special kind of taxation on rice levied by the grand shrines).

sen.j: こうした国衙から当該令制国への賦課を11世紀中頃から「国役」と称するようになっていった。

sen.j: 12世紀に入ると、在庁官人などが国役の一環として在家役を課して公領把握に努めるようになる。
sen.e: In the 12th century, Zaichokanjin (the local officials in Heian and Kamakura periods) imposed Zaikeyaku (taxation on residents) as one of the kuniyaku and strived to grasp Koryo (an Imperial demesne).

sen.j: 鎌倉時代に入ると、朝廷による一国平均役が鎌倉幕府や守護の関与を得ながらも国役として展開される事になる。
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, the Imperial Court began to develop the Ikkoku heikinyaku as kuniyaku with involvement by the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable) and Shugo (provincial constable).

sen.j: 南北朝の戦乱の中で守護領国制が形成されていく中で室町幕府及び在地を支配する守護大名が朝廷・国衙に代わって国役の賦課・免除の権限を掌握するようになる。
sen.e: As Shugo-ryogoku system (the system that a Shugo dominates a manor) was formed during wars between the Northern and Southern Courts, the Muromachi bakufu and Shugo daimyo which controlled lands secured the authority to impose or exempt kuniyaku on behalf of the Imperial Court and kokuga.

During the formation of the Shugo-ryogoku system at the time of the wars between the Northern and Southern Courts, the Muromachi bakufu and Shugo daimyo, who controlled lands, took over the authority to impose or exempt public duties or taxes from the Imperial Court and provincial officials.

sen.j: こうした国役は室町幕府・守護大名の没落で消滅する。
sen.e: The kuniyaku disappeared with the fall of the Muromachi bakufu and Shugo daimyo.
